articles.headline: Critics of War Spare Senator in Close Race
articles.snippet: Pragmatism among antiwar Democrats seems to have buoyed a Washington senator’s campaign.
articles.abstract: Pragmatism among antiwar Democrats seems to have buoyed a Washington senator’s campaign.

articles.headline: Retailers See Strong Sales for Holidays
articles.snippet: The National Retail Federation will predict a sales increase of 5 percent, to $457.4 billion, compared with last year.
articles.abstract: The National Retail Federation will predict a sales increase of 5 percent, to $457.4 billion, compared with last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The holidays may not be so bad after all.

articles.headline: It’s Muslim Boy Meets Girl, but Don’t Call It Dating
articles.snippet: The largest Muslim conference in North America hosted speed dating sessions called the “matrimonial banquet.”
articles.abstract: The largest Muslim conference in North America hosted speed dating sessions called the “matrimonial banquet.”
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — So here’s the thing about speed dating for Muslims.

articles.headline: A Hedge Fund’s Loss Rattles Nerves
articles.snippet: Enormous losses at Amaranth Advisors resurrected worries that major bets by hedge funds could create widespread financial disruptions.
articles.abstract: Enormous losses at Amaranth Advisors resurrected worries that major bets by hedge funds could create widespread financial disruptions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Enormous losses at one of the nation’s largest hedge funds resurrected worries yesterday that major bets by these secretive, unregulated investment partnerships could create widespread financial disruptions.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Democrat, Republican and a Bond of Addiction
articles.snippet: Patrick J. Kennedy, a Democrat who pleaded guilty to impaired driving, has a Republican sponsor.
articles.abstract: Patrick J. Kennedy, a Democrat who pleaded guilty to impaired driving, has a Republican sponsor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 — Scenes from an uncommon political marriage:

articles.headline: On India’s Farms, a Plague of Suicide
articles.snippet: India’s economy may be soaring, but the agricultural industry remains its Achilles’ heel. In 2003, 17,107 farmers committed suicide.
articles.abstract: India’s economy may be soaring, but the agricultural industry remains its Achilles’ heel. In 2003, 17,107 farmers committed suicide.
articles.lead_paragraph: BHADUMARI, India — Here in the center of India, on a gray Wednesday morning, a cotton farmer swallowed a bottle of pesticide and fell dead at the threshold of his small mud house.

articles.headline: Oil’s Rout Outpaces Its Advance
articles.snippet: As crude oil prices have plunged, many traders say they have been dumping and short-selling stocks and futures contracts.
articles.abstract: As crude oil prices have plunged, many traders say they have been dumping and short-selling stocks and futures contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Sept. 18 — Michael Rose, the director of the energy trading desk at Angus Jackson in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has made a lot of money for his clients by riding energy prices up the escalator of recent years.

articles.headline: Canadians Fault U.S. for Its Role in Torture Case
articles.snippet: Four years after he was deported to Syria, where he was tortured, a Canadian man was exonerated by a government panel of any ties to terrorism.
articles.abstract: Four years after he was deported to Syria, where he was tortured, a Canadian man was exonerated by a government panel of any ties to terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Sept. 18 — A government commission on Monday exonerated a Canadian computer engineer of any ties to terrorism and issued a scathing report that faulted Canada and the United States for his deportation four years ago to Syria, where he was imprisoned and tortured.

articles.headline: A Corporate Nanny Turns Assertive
articles.snippet: A court-authorized overseer monitoring Bristol-Myers Squibb successfully recommended that the board dismiss the chief executive.
articles.abstract: A court-authorized overseer monitoring Bristol-Myers Squibb successfully recommended that the board dismiss the chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Bristol-Myers Squibb chief executive, Peter R. Dolan, sought to blunt a federal prosecutor’s investigation of the company in 2003, he made a seemingly canny move. Mr. Dolan retained the adviser’s services of a former federal judge greatly admired by the prosecutor.

articles.headline: On India’s Farms, a Plague of Suicide
articles.snippet: Here in the center of India, on a gray Wednesday morning, a cotton farmer swallowed a bottle of pesticide and fell dead at the threshold of his small mud house.      The farmer, Anil Kondba Shende, 31, left behind a wife and two small sons, debts ...
articles.abstract: Here in the center of India, on a gray Wednesday morning, a cotton farmer swallowed a bottle of pesticide and fell dead at the threshold of his small mud house.      The farmer, Anil Kondba Shende, 31, left behind a wife and two small sons, debts that his family knew about only vaguely and a soggy, ruined 3.5-acre patch of cotton plants that had been his only source of income.
articles.lead_paragraph: BHADUMARI, India - Here in the center of India, on a gray Wednesday morning, a cotton farmer swallowed a bottle of pesticide and fell dead at the threshold of his small mud house.

articles.headline: Democrat, Republican and a Bond of Addiction
articles.snippet: Scenes from an uncommon political marriage:     Representative Jim Ramstad, a Republican from Minnesota, and Patrick J. Kennedy, a Democrat from Rhode Island, are deep in conversation on the House floor, Mr. Ramstad's hand draped over his colleagu...
articles.abstract: Scenes from an uncommon political marriage:     Representative Jim Ramstad, a Republican from Minnesota, and Patrick J. Kennedy, a Democrat from Rhode Island, are deep in conversation on the House floor, Mr. Ramstad's hand draped over his colleague's shoulder.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 - Scenes from an uncommon political marriage:

articles.headline: A Corporate Nanny Turns Assertive
articles.snippet: When the Bristol-Myers Squibb chief executive, Peter R. Dolan, sought to blunt a federal prosecutor's investigation of the company in 2003, he made a seemingly canny move. Mr. Dolan retained the adviser's services of a former federal judge greatly...
articles.abstract: When the Bristol-Myers Squibb chief executive, Peter R. Dolan, sought to blunt a federal prosecutor's investigation of the company in 2003, he made a seemingly canny move. Mr. Dolan retained the adviser's services of a former federal judge greatly admired by the prosecutor.     Three years later, Mr. Dolan must be regretting that choice.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Bristol-Myers Squibb chief executive, Peter R. Dolan, sought to blunt a federal prosecutor's investigation of the company in 2003, he made a seemingly canny move. Mr. Dolan retained the adviser's services of a former federal judge greatly admired by the prosecutor.

articles.headline: Oil’s Rout Outpaces Its Advance
articles.snippet: Michael Rose, the director of the energy trading desk at Angus Jackson in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has made a lot of money for his clients by riding energy prices up the escalator of recent years.      But with fading risks of supply disruptions fro...
articles.abstract: Michael Rose, the director of the energy trading desk at Angus Jackson in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has made a lot of money for his clients by riding energy prices up the escalator of recent years.      But with fading risks of supply disruptions from things like a hurricane in the Gulf of Mexico or the rise in tensions with Iran, he started changing his position earlier this summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Sept. 18 - Michael Rose, the director of the energy trading desk at Angus Jackson in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has made a lot of money for his clients by riding energy prices up the escalator of recent years.

articles.headline: Critics of War Spare Senator in Close Race
articles.snippet: Even as Senator Maria Cantwell of Washington has faced frequent criticism for having voted for the war in Iraq, her re-election campaign appears to be benefiting from a cold dose of pragmatism among many of her fellow Democrats.     After looking ...
articles.abstract: Even as Senator Maria Cantwell of Washington has faced frequent criticism for having voted for the war in Iraq, her re-election campaign appears to be benefiting from a cold dose of pragmatism among many of her fellow Democrats.     After looking east to Connecticut, where another supporter of the war, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, lost the Democratic primary last month, many Democrats here say attacking Ms. Cantwell in Tuesday's primary seems flat-out foolish because it could benefit the well-financed Republican challenger in November.

articles.headline: It’s Muslim Boy Meets Girl, but Don’t Call It Dating
articles.snippet: So here's the thing about speed dating for Muslims.      Many American Muslims -- or at least those bent on maintaining certain conservative traditions -- equate anything labeled ''dating'' with hellfire, no matter how short a time is involved. He...
articles.abstract: So here's the thing about speed dating for Muslims.      Many American Muslims -- or at least those bent on maintaining certain conservative traditions -- equate anything labeled ''dating'' with hellfire, no matter how short a time is involved. Hence the wildly popular speed dating sessions at the largest annual Muslim conference in North America were given an entirely more respectable label. They were called the ''matrimonial banquet.''
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO - So here's the thing about speed dating for Muslims.

articles.headline: A Hedge Fund’s Loss Rattles Nerves
articles.snippet: Enormous losses at one of the nation's largest hedge funds resurrected worries yesterday that major bets by these secretive, unregulated investment partnerships could create widespread financial disruptions.     The hedge fund, Amaranth Advisors, ...
articles.abstract: Enormous losses at one of the nation's largest hedge funds resurrected worries yesterday that major bets by these secretive, unregulated investment partnerships could create widespread financial disruptions.     The hedge fund, Amaranth Advisors, based in Greenwich, Conn., made an estimated $1 billion on rising energy prices last year. Yesterday, the fund told its investors that it had lost more than $3 billion in the recent downturn in natural gas and that it was working with its lenders and selling its holdings ''to protect our investors.''
articles.lead_paragraph: Enormous losses at one of the nation's largest hedge funds resurrected worries yesterday that major bets by these secretive, unregulated investment partnerships could create widespread financial disruptions.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Canadians Fault U.S. for Its Role in Torture Case
articles.snippet: A government commission on Monday exonerated a Canadian computer engineer of any ties to terrorism and issued a scathing report that faulted Canada and the United States for his deportation four years ago to Syria, where he was imprisoned and tort...
articles.abstract: A government commission on Monday exonerated a Canadian computer engineer of any ties to terrorism and issued a scathing report that faulted Canada and the United States for his deportation four years ago to Syria, where he was imprisoned and tortured.      The report on the engineer, Maher Arar, said American officials had apparently acted on inaccurate information from Canadian investigators and then misled Canadian authorities about their plans for Mr. Arar before transporting him to Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Sept. 18 - A government commission on Monday exonerated a Canadian computer engineer of any ties to terrorism and issued a scathing report that faulted Canada and the United States for his deportation four years ago to Syria, where he was imprisoned and tortured.

articles.headline: Retailers See Strong Sales for Holidays
articles.snippet: The holidays may not be so bad after all.     After months of hand-wringing over higher gas prices and a sluggish housing market, which threatened to reduce spending in the crucial November-to-December period, the nation's retailers are beginning ...
articles.abstract: The holidays may not be so bad after all.     After months of hand-wringing over higher gas prices and a sluggish housing market, which threatened to reduce spending in the crucial November-to-December period, the nation's retailers are beginning to talk about an above-average shopping season.
articles.lead_paragraph: The holidays may not be so bad after all.
